ai-ud5.1:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud5.1:1.3_0: Just then King Pasenadi of Kosala was up in his best stilt house with queen Mallikā
ai-ud5.1:1.4_0: Then King Pasenadi addressed Queen Mallikā,
ai-ud5.1:1.5_0: “Is there anyone, Mallikā, you love more than yourself?”
ai-ud5.1:2.2_0: But is there anyone more dear to you than yourself?”
ai-ud5.1:3.1_0: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala came downstairs from the stilt longhouse,
ai-ud5.1:3.2_0: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,
ai-ud5.1:4.1_0: “Here, reverend Sir, having gone to the top of the royal palace with Queen Mallikā said to her,
ai-ud5.1:4.2_0: ‘Is there anyone, Mallikā, you love more than yourself?’
ai-ud5.1:4.3_0: When this was said, Queen Mallikā said this to me:
ai-ud5.1:4.4_0: ‘There is no one, Great King, I love more than myself.
ai-ud5.1:4.5_0: But is there anyone more dear to you than yourself?’
ai-ud5.1:4.6_0: When this was said, I said to her,
ai-ud5.1:5.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud5.1:6.1_0: I visited all quarters with my mind
ai-ud5.1:6.2_0: one finds no-one dearer than oneself.
ai-ud5.1:6.3_0: In the same way others each love themselves,
ai-ud5.1:6.4_0: so one who loves themselves would harm no other.”
